instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Hi Team,

I Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no backlight:

F9800 is OK
at <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>:
Pin 2 <SIGNAL>BKLT_PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>, I have 3.298V
pin 5 <SIGNAL>LVDS_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> I have 0V that's why it can't provide a gnd for the Div bridge to be able to close <TRANSISTOR>Q9806</TRANSISTOR>.....

Now the <SIGNAL>LVDS_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> line is directly provided by <CHIP>U9600</CHIP>, I've checked for eventual broken trace, but no........

So what would be the next step please? replace the <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> or there is something else to check before doing that replacement as I'm not sure to have an <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is stock / donor board.....

Question: should I plug the screen for the <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> to send that signal?

Thanks, Gracias

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Hi
OK I plugged the screen and I have <SIGNAL>LVDS_BKL_ON</SIGNAL> , <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> is closing to send the enable signal to <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>.
<RESISTOR>R9730</RESISTOR> is 61KOhms but should be 0.1 Ohms
Will replace it and let you know

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Backlight and LVDS/eDP circuitries always need LCD to be connected!!!

If <RESISTOR>R9730</RESISTOR> is bad, check for any short on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.
Probably nothing, if <RESISTOR>R9730</RESISTOR> is only corroded.
If is burnt, that will point to a short somewhere...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Hi,
I replaced <RESISTOR>R9730</RESISTOR>, but Honnestly i'm suspecting the lcd screen that kills the backlight  because it' does not have the locking latch, also the client reported backlight issue after replacing the original screen with this one (used one)
​​I will check for any short Last week i've already replaced F9800 and tested the board with another screen and it was OK. 
But this time i don't have that spare screen to test the board and as i'm suspecting the client used screen i will not plug it to test it. 
At least i'll have a look for any short and wait next week to get a known good screen. 
Gracias

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Don't close the LCD connector, or at least check if the closing latch has the plastic protector in good condition.
Compare resistance to ground from backlight rail w/ and w/o screen connected...
